maintenanceevent.eventdescription: Finding aid encoded by Library of Congress Manuscript Division

did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: U.S. Air Force officer and U.S. Army officer. Correspondence, speeches, writings, reports, newspaper clippings, scrapbooks, awards, maps, photographs, and other papers relating chiefly to Doolittle's service in the U.S. Air Force.

controlaccess.head: Selected Search Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the LC Catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The papers of James Harold Doolittle, U.S Air Force officer and U.S. Army officer, were given to the Library of Congress by Doolittle in 1974. Additional material was given by Lee R. Magnolia from 1988 to 1990.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: The James Harold Doolittle Papers were housed and described in 1975 and expanded in 2016. The finding aid was revised in 2013 and 2016.

separatedmaterial.head: Transfers
separatedmaterial.p: Record albums have been transferred to the Library's Motion Picture, Broadcasting, and Recorded Sound Division where they are identified as part of these papers.

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: The status of copyright in the unpublished writings of James H. Doolittle is governed by the Copyright Law of the United States (Title 17, U.S.C.).

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The papers of James Harold Doolittle are open to research. Researchers are advised to contact the Manuscript Reading Room prior to visiting. Many collections are stored off-site and advance notice is needed to retrieve these items for research use.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: Container number, James Harold Doolittle Papers, Manuscript Division, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The papers of James H. Doolittle (1896-1993) span the years 1919-1990, with the bulk of the material concentrated in the period 1940-1960 and consisting of correspondence, speeches, writings, reports, newspaper clippings, scrapbooks, awards, maps, photographs, and other papers relating chiefly to Doolittle's service in the United States Air Force. Doolittle had a long career as a civilian and military aviator, government official and adviser, and business executive, but he was most celebrated for directing and leading an air raid on Tokyo in the early months of World War II against Japan. The collection is organized into seven series: Correspondence File , General File , National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics , Speeches and Articles , Miscellany , Addition , and Oversize .

Included in the collection are military records of Doolittle and a large amount of photographs and printed material. In general, the correspondence contains routine discussions of business matters, hunting trips, social affairs, and reunions of the American fliers who attacked Tokyo in April 1942. Materials relating to the raid include a map of Japan signed by some of the participants, telegrams from Generals George C. Marshall and Henry Harley Arnold, a handwritten memorandum from Admiral Ernest Joseph King, and letters of thanks and appreciation from Admiral William F. Halsey and May Ling-Soong Chiang. Additional correspondents from the war period include letters from Dwight D. Eisenhower, George S. Patton, Carl Spaatz, and Maxwell D. Taylor.

An addition to the papers includes correspondence, articles about Doolittle, and a photograph showing a formation of B-25s in dual mode. Most of the correspondence consists of short notes from Doolittle thanking Lee R. Magnolia for sending clippings related to aviation, aerospace, politics, whaling, and other topics.

arrangement.head: Arrangement of the Papers
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged in seven series:
Arranged alphabetically by name of correspondent and therein chronologically.

scopecontent.p: Correspondence, memoranda, invitations, reports, lists, studies, printed matter, and miscellaneous material.

arrangement.p: Arranged by subject or type of material.
